Posts.Content: Sep 20, 2007 11:00PM - edited Sep 20, 2007 11:03PM by ravdeb Laura.... I agree with you on a certain level. It's all about how one markets something. I was getting the feeling when I was in the States that it was actually a "cool" thing to have bc as opposed to a scary thing. It's now very in to wear necklaces with bc ribbons on them. I was given one by a woman who had bc and is now making them. And I love it and have worn it. But, it's popular to have bc now. I mean..it's prevalant but it's also a "popular" thing and the "in" thing. In some ways this is good for those who are suffering with it. It almost puts us in a fairy tale existence while we go through chemo. It's like it's okay...even good to have it. And that's where I stop. It is NOT good. It's deadly. It's NOT pink. And in fact, it's not a woman's disease. My uncle died of breast cancer. I didn't know this until this summer. (he was not a blood relative of mine). I agree...people need to be aware of it and get early detection. People need to help us find a cure. I agree. I think the walks are a terrific way of raising funds, meeting others with bc or those who are friends and families or just supporters for the cause. And I think that the fact there are so many walks across America, there is lots of awareness. I think the talks that people give like Tracy is doing and her work with ACS is terrific. Over our Rosh HaShana holiday a rabbi in Illinois gave her sermon about awareness of BRACA after a congregant died of ovarian cancer. I'm all for that. I'm not for the pink (pink is one of my fav colors but I won't admit to it! I do like purple when I'm not into pink!) that is everywhere and every little thing you buy has something about giving to breast cancer. I AM for teaching others about it and making them more aware. I don't even trust those companies and wonder if my money is really going there. Okay..I'm off my soap box. My mom is out of surgery. She had a knee replacement. Just spoke to my dad. I wish I was there. I had my flight arrangements before I knew she needed surgery. I wanted to stay but I needed to get home. My dad is well equipped to care for her. Still....she's in pain but in good spirits and wanted to know when she could start her exercising. She is not even out of surgery 24 hours! Be well, Ladies.

Posts.Content: Sep 27, 2007 12:33PM - edited Sep 27, 2007 12:35PM by ravdeb You are supposed to avoid all extreme temps to avoid LE...I just read on the lymphedema theads that the new research shows that the snb is not as successful in reducing the risk of lymphedema as they had hoped and so all of us..even those of us with only one node removed...are at risk. There are other factors as well such as being overweight, if it's your dominant side or not and some other stuff..not sure what.... Kelly..I like the cartoon. It is so true. Most people here get Fridays and Saturdays off of work. Teachers work 5 days a week meaning that nobody works on Saturdays but teachers have to schedule in their other day off as there is school at most schools on Fridays. And yes..they get holidays off...the schools, for example, are off for a week for Sukkot but business have one or two days off and then are open during the week of the holiday. Then they will close again at the end of Sukkot for the holiday of Simchat Torah. Confusing, I know. Nothing closes for Chanukah as that is not a religious holiday and is our least important holiday of the year. The holiday lasts 8 days but school is closed for about 3 days out of that holiday. The longer mid-year school holiday is in the spring for Passover...school is closed for 2 and a half weeks. My dh only takes Yom Kippur off. He has to. Nobody...I mean NOBODY works on this holy day here in Israel. Otherwise, he takes no days off unless we decide to go away for a weekend (rare) or he goes with me to the States (summer 2008 he plans to go with me for 2 weeks). Such is life....

Posts.Content: Nov 22, 2008 06:05AM ravdeb wrote: There is a serious controversy in the medical world, it appears to me, as to the use of breast MRI's. In some cases it is necessary and in others they feel it is not. Â My lump was seen on the mammo and ultrasound because I found it first and it was visible with the naked eye because it was just under the skin (and I still wonder when it popped up so suddenly). Â I have extremely dense breasts and the radiologist says that my mammos and ultrasound are useless. Last year I requested a breast MRI and the insurance rejected it (even though my oncologist spoke to the head doctor in the insurance about it) because the mammo showed my first lump. This year my onco requested it again and I got the MRI. It showed my affected side to be fine (this is already 3 years after diagnosis) but my right side has an abnormal spot that needs to be followed up. I did US and mammo and of course, they didn't see it. It's very tiny. I have a follow up MRI in December at a different hospital and it will be interesting to see if they see it. MRI's pick up everything. The doctor who analyzes it must be well trained and experienced to distinguish between the benign abnormalities and something that warrants a biopsy. Well..that's what they told me. I'm just repeating what I've been told. My personal onc told me to pay for the MRI and do it every 2-3 years. On the other years do mammo and ultrasound. I doubt I'll do anymore mammos..just my personal feeling..because for me it's wasted, painful and just gives me more radiation because she can't read them anyway. Â They are not using MRI's as a regular screening process and it is really just diagnostic or for those with very dense breasts. Well..again..that's what I read.

Posts.Content: Jan 31, 2008 03:37PM ravdeb wrote: YES!!! I have Horner's Syndrome. I was diagnosed with this in 2003. I had a headache above my left eye (interestingly, my bc was on the left side) and went to a general neurologist who sent me to a neuro-ophthalmologist. She tested the eye with a series of cocaine drops and that is how you can tell if you have Horners Syndrome. I have a droopy eyelid and pupil doesn't dilate. Horner's syndrome is a symptom of other conditions. They didn't find a brain tumor. I have a dissected carotid artery. This causes the horners syndrome. Don't wait.. see a neurologist and ask for a brain scan and a CT angio which is a vascular ct. It was the CT angio that showed the dissected artery(common cause of horners..). It's important to know what the cause of the syndrome is. Be sure to beÂ TESTED for Horners syndrome. It's important to know if it's REALLY horners syndrome. Horners syndrome in and of itself is harmless. You eye will never close all the way. It's the CAUSE of it that can be deadly.. Please get this checked out! I'm under care of a few doctors for this. Good luck.
Posts.Title: Anyone with Horner's Syndrome? djz2003 Kerrilyn

Posts.Content: Feb 1, 2008 02:07AM ravdeb wrote: Maybe this is what your onc meant..your lung mets are in a place that can cause Horners...Â  A pancoast tumor, also pancoast tumour (UK) or superior sulcus tumor, is a tumor of the pulmonary apex i.e. a type of lung cancer defined primarily by its location situated at the top end of either the right or left lung. The growing tumor can cause compression of a brachiocephalic vein, subclavian artery, phrenic nerve, recurrent laryngeal nerve, or, characteristically, compression of a sympathetic ganglion resulting in a range of symptoms known as Horner's syndrome. Pancoast tumors are named for Henry Pancoast, a US radiologist, who described them in 1924 and 1932.

How Do You Handle All of the Phone Calls? figsgirls joanne_elizabeth

Posts.Content: Sep 27, 2007 07:11AM ravdeb wrote: I was also told by my oncologists and surgeons that I didn't need a sleeve/gauntlet for flights. Nothing happened the first time I flew overseas but this year I decided no to take any chances. I got my breast surgeon to write that I do need it even though he doesn't agree. The LE therapist recommends it. I got sleeve and gauntlet and honestly, I took a long flight of over 10 hours and I had no discomfort with the sleeve or gauntlet, no swelling...no nothing. It's so worth preventing a problem. You can usually get an off the shelf variety for prevention only. This is what I got. I had it fitted by an LE therapist but didn't need a custom made one. I am still not sure if my insurance will cover it...must go check on that. I filled out all the papers. You'll be surprised to see other people wearing these things on the flights. There is a controversy as to whether LE can occur because of a flight and I say that until proven otherwise, I'm taking precautions.
